name: Megan Thee Stallion
description:
'''Megan Jovon Ruth Pete''' (born February 15, 1995), known professionally as '''Megan Thee Stallion''',{{efn|Pronounced "the", not "[[thee]]". Specifically, she pronounces the "Thee" as an unstressed {{IPAc-en|ð|ə}}, and not {{IPAc-en|ð|iː}} as in [[thee]] or a stressed the.<ref>{{cite web|title = Megan Thee Stallion's ABCs|via = [[YouTube]]| date=July 9, 2019 |url-status = live |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20190727220004/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0DxH8RGNKDY|archive-date = July 27, 2019|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0DxH8RGNKDY|access-date = July 29, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = Megan Thee Stallion Sings Rihanna, Beyoncé and Khalid in a Game of Song Association| via = [[YouTube]]| date = June 27, 2019| url-status = live | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20190715160018/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aBR7676_Rr4| archive-date = July 15, 2019| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aBR7676_Rr4| access-date = July 29, 2019}}</ref>}} is an American rapper and actress. She gained recognition when videos of her [[freestyling]] began to circulate widely on [[social media]], leading her to sign with [[1501 Certified Entertainment]] in 2018.

Megan achieved mainstream success the following year with the release of her commercial mixtape [[Fever (mixtape)|''Fever'']] (2019), followed by the [[extended play]] ''[[Suga (EP)|Suga]]'' (2020), both of which peaked within the top ten of the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart. She had her breakthrough with her 2019 singles "[[Hot Girl Summer]]" (featuring [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Ty Dolla Sign]]) and "[[Cash Shit]]" (featuring [[DaBaby]]); her 2020 single, "[[Savage (Megan Thee Stallion song)|Savage]]", spawned a remix [[Beyoncé]] that won two [[Grammy Award]]s, peaked atop the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], and was included on her debut studio album [[Good News (Megan Thee Stallion album)|''Good News'']] (2020). Its single "[[Body (Megan Thee Stallion song)|Body]]" made her the first female act to release three number-one songs on the [[Streaming Songs]] chart within a year. That same year, she guest appeared on [[Cardi B]]'s single "[[WAP (song)|WAP]]", which became her second number one song on the Hot 100.

Megan's [[compilation album]] ''[[Something for Thee Hotties]]'' (2021) peaked at number five on the ''Billboard'' 200 and included the Grammy Award-nominated top-20 single "[[Thot Shit]]". Following the shooting trial after she was shot in the foot by [[Tory Lanez]], as well as contractual issues with her record label, she left both 1501 and [[300 Entertainment]]. Megan's second studio album, ''[[Traumazine]]'' (2022), included the single "[[Sweetest Pie]]" (with [[Dua Lipa]])—which peaked at number 15 in the US—and served as her final release with the aforementioned labels. She founded her own record label, Hot Girl Productions, in 2023, through which she released her third studio album, [[Megan (album)|''Megan'']] (2024). It spawned the single "[[Hiss (song)|Hiss]]", which became Megan's first solo song to top the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and made her the first solo female rapper to debut atop the [[Billboard Global 200|''Billboard'' Global 200]].

Megan is the recipient of [[List of awards and nominations received by Megan Thee Stallion|various accolades]], including six [[BET Awards]], five [[BET Hip Hop Awards]], four [[American Music Awards]], four [[MTV Video Music Awards]], a [[Billboard Women in Music|''Billboard'' Women in Music Award]], and three [[Grammy Awards]]. At the [[63rd Annual Grammy Awards]], she became the second female rapper to win [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] (after [[Lauryn Hill]] in [[41st Annual Grammy Awards|1999]]). [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] included her on its list of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]] in 2020. Outside of music, she has ventured into television and film, headlining the documentary film titled ''[[Megan Thee Stallion: In Her Words]]'' (2024).
